Award.AwardTitle: Analysis and geometry of metric measure spaces
Award.AbstractNarration:
Geometry and analysis have become increasingly important to real world applications in the last few decades. We are now capable of gathering immense amounts of data, and so it is a central concern to develop quick and efficient ways of analyzing this data. In many instances, one can endow the points of a data set with a notion of distance and weight, thereby giving us a geometric representation of the data. One can then try to take advantage of this geometry and leverage this information to speed up computations on the data set. This project seeks to develop new techniques and theorems for understanding the geometric and analytic structure of spaces with some notion of distance and (possibly) weight. Some basic questions the project will address are the following: Can I represent my space in some other space (e.g. Euclidean space) so that the geometry is preserved with high fidelity? Does my space exhibit low dimensional behavior despite living in a possibly high (or infinite) dimensional space? Is there a calculus available on my space that I can use to analyze functions on the space?

This project will study analytic and geometric properties of certain classes of metric measure spaces. In the first part of the project, the PI will study problems about metric embeddings including whether doubling subsets of Hilbert space embed into Euclidean spaces and developing biLipschitz metric invariants to measure uniform smoothness. The second part of the project will focus on detecting rectifiable behavior in metric measure spaces. Rectifiable spaces admit parameterizations by simple model spaces (usually Euclidean space) and so can exhibit low dimensional behavior. The PI will study Carnot notions of rectifiability and also link these geometric properties to boundedness of singular integrals. Finally, the PI will continue his study into the nature of Lipschitz differentiability on metric measure spaces as introduced by Cheeger. The project will determine whether such differentiation differs between real valued and RNP Banach space valued functions. If these notions turn out to be different, the PI will then seek to discover the geometric mechanisms for the former (the PI has already been geometrically characterized the latter). The PI will also seek to broaden the differentiability theory to non-Banach space target.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this project, we studied the geometry of Carnot groups, which are mathematical objects that model geometric spaces of constrained motion.  Carnot groups resemble Euclidean space (in fact, Euclidean spaces are special kinds of Carnot groups). Indeed, they exhibit many qualities one might find in a vector space.  A key difference is that Carnot groups are noncommutative, that is, that traveling in a circle may not bring you back to your beginning point.

 

One of our main results is a study of what allows a set of a Carnot group to be visited in finite time.  It turns out such sets must resemble straight lines on small scales in a quantitative way. This is an analogue of a similar theorem in the Euclidean setting.

 

This is important in the study of robotics.  Indeed, the space of possible configurations for a robot can be thought of as a geometric space with restricted motion as a robot can only move according to its specifications (a rotating joint, an extending arm, etc.).

 

One question one might want to ask is whether a robot might achieve a certain set of configurations using only permitted motion.  In essence, one asks if one can visit this set of configurations in finite time. Our result advances the theoretical understanding of this problem by showing that if the set of configurations is far from a straight line (in some concrete mathematical sense) for many locations and scale, then the answer is either no, or the time required to visit each configuration may be large.

 

Another key result we achieved defining an infinite dimensional variant of Carnot groups and proving that a large class of functions on these spaces have many points of differentiability.  This project sought to merge the study of Carnot groups with the field of functional analysis (which can be roughly thought of as infinite dimensional linear algebra). This allows us to develop a noncommutative version of infinite dimensional calculus.
